license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
According to the Ancient History Encyclopedia, the Hindu elephant-headed god Ganesha is the "patron of writers, travellers, students, commerce, and new projects (for which he removes obstacles from one's path) and is rather fond of sweets, to the slight detriment of his figure." The original statue was purchased in Ahmedabad, India. 

This model was scanned using Trnio and then processed with MeshLab and Meshmixer. To see a walkthrough of how it was made, see our Tutorial Tuesday article Full-Color Prints, Starting With Trnio Photogrammetry.

Download the STL for free here, or buy a Full-Color Sandstone print of this model at Shapeways.

This sword is about right for your 2 to 6 year-old dragon-slayer.  Adult-sized version also available.

In addition to the printed parts, this sword uses a length of foam pipe insulation (0.48" ID, 1.25" OD)and a 1/4" (or maybe 6 mm) diameter rod or dowel (I used steel, but wood would work) and hot glue or other adhesive of your choice.  
Print the handle and the blade plug.  The handle will benefit from support at the blade stud.  Don't worry about surface finish there; it gets covered up anyway.  The full tang means your handle shouldn't need to be super-sturdy, but I printed at 0.2 mm layers and 100% infill because my kids are hard on things.  
The "big-hilt" file is adult sized.  I was jealous of my kids' swords.  Construction is otherwise identical.  
Drill out the holes if needed to fit your rod.  Cut the pipe insulation to the desired blade length (roughly 18").  Cut the rod to length (handle length + blade length - 2 inches).  Note that the blade will overhang the rod when the rod goes all the way to the end of the handle, to make a soft point.  
Place some hot glue inside the plug and run it over the rod, until the rod is flush with one end.  Put some hot glue in the hole in the handle and likewise run the rod in until it's flush to the bottom (it's a full tang).  There are recesses inside the handle and plug to hold glue, so you can use a fair amount.  
A caution: hot glue will melt some pipe insulation, so don't use too much during assembly.  
Place some hot glue on the handle stud and run the pipe insulation over the plug, over the rod, and up to the hilt of the handle.  The plug should be recessed by that 2 inches, leaving a soft "point" for the blade.  With the blade vertical, squirt a little (not too much) hot glue down that hole to bond the blade to the plug.  Wait for it to cool before playtime.  
Now have fun storming the castle!

title: CAR Roof bag DIY Horizontal hook
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Hi people !

This is 3D printed hook for homemade Horizontal Rod for fixing a roof bag on a car
This hook is designed for FIAT PANDA 2004 series roof rod but can fit on other car too, you have to check the compatibility of my work to your car.
Those hook can actually wear 50 Kg in the roof bag and more (on the picture, i'm inside and weigh 59 Kg )
With solidwork study of resistance, the whole structure (with aluminium rectangular profile so called Alu PAF can support more than 300 Kg, i will not try that much but it can theorically speaking)
I tested this at 20 Km/h to 120 km/h with 40 Kg inside and done a quick brake test to see if it broke, nothing broke and nothing moved even 1 mm

I highly recommend to use ABS / ABS-PC / NYLON for this, high resitance, nearly no flexibility and a high melting point due to climatic reason.

I highly recommend to do a smooth heat treatment to your pieces for smoothing surface and limit the possibility of fissure in very long therm or brutal use.

This project will required you :
-8 M8 L90 H/CHC screw
-8 M8 large washer
-4 M8 bolt
-4 My NYLSTOP bolt
-12 M6 L50 H/CHC screw
-12 M6 NYLSTOP bolt
-Anti slip tape
-*2 Aluminium rectangulare tube 48/32 4mm thick (you can use other rectangulare size, check what you can get close to this, don't touch the thickness) for my car it was 1200 mm long (fiat panda 2004), check for yours.

WARNING for your security
1 DOn't print this if you have a floppy sloppy 3d printer, be strict about the quality of what you print because YOUR LIFE and OTHER PEOPLE LIFE can be in danger if you make something that break on the road !
2 TAKE SERIOUS CONCERN about the whole description of this project
3 BE STRICT about the quality of what you print
4 IF YOU ARE SKILLED and have a small butane firetorch, try to make a heat threatment, it prevent future crack and smooth surface.
5 All the parameter i tell here are fonctionnal for my car, if you move a things i can't garanty you the same result as me.
6 This is my project, i would be very of you to take picture of you around the world with this, really :)
7 I don't allow people to sell this with any kind of profit ! This project by just 3D printing cost 30€ no more for the electricity and plastic, i say this because i don't want to find any kind of profit on this work. It is made for helping, not for making your buisness you crazy 3d printer addict :D
8 The weigh i have tested was 58 Kg not in movement and +-40Kg in movement. My roof bag is for 50 kg maximum in movement. Don't go over this or make lot of test before really going on vacation
9 I'm not responsible of your act and what happen to you with this project
10 Look about your country legislation

Steps:
1 Make sure the parameter and quotations fit to what you need.

2 Print the parts and by the Alu PAF and screw/bolt

3 Heat treatment

4 Put non slip tape in the inside place where it will grip on the longitudinal rod, it hold in place the structure while drinvand and limit vibration/slipping

5 Fix the four hook on the longitudinal rod where they belong the best about you roof bag and symmetrical (i didn't mention it later but i checked every movement and everything every distance for having a perfect symmetry)

6 With a pen, draw the front6/6back M6 holes position on the AluPAF and drill them

7 Fix all the screw and bolt

8 Fix your roof bag

9 Drink a beer, or a tea if you"re soft but don't drink and drive. Beer and Tea are precious.

If you have any question feel free to tell me.
Like sayd before, if you built this thanks to send me picture of your travel around the world.
You can follow WavePro on Facebook for new's or question
-https://www.facebook.com/WaveProduction-898263533576863/

For more detail:
I'm the legal owner and first maker of this spetial part and no tiers can claim this work is him.

Feel free to drop a like or to share this project to people you think need it.

author: brettwal

title: Stand for Nokia DT-900 Qi Wireless Cell Phone Charger

description.text:
This is a simple stand for Nokia's DT-900 Qi Wireless Cell Phone Charger. I made it to support my Nokia Lumia 920--but it should work for pretty much any Qi-enabled phone, including some models from Samsung, Nokia, etc. Unlike some of the other stands out there, I left the back open, and added couple of small vents on the front, to help relieve heat while charging.  
It prints with three supports--one big one on the back, and two tiny ones on the front. I've attached the SketchUp file so that you can modify it if you like.  
I printed a copy in glow-in-the-dark PLA for on by bedstand, so that I don't have to hunt for the charger once the lights go out. Works great!

Designed in SketchUp. Printed with MakerWare on a Makerbot Replicator 2 (PLA). Default settings worked great.  
This is my first 3D project, so I had quite a learning curve!

description.text:
I usually buy wooden pants hangers:

The problem is that the plastic part breaks if you put something too thick on it. I usually do that...

So I printed a replacement

I first tried making just the plastic part, and then inserting the metal hook into it. This turned out ok, but it is a ton of work. So I just printed a plastic hook to go with it.
I gave it a big space where the two parts meet so that it can rotate

The parts are split so you can print them flat and then glue together (You have to assemble the small hook part first and then glue the large hook with the smaller part inside)

Fusion360 and obj files are here:
[Github]( https://github.com/acegas/PantHangerFix )

I design this to test the best settings for new filaments with minimal material to save time and cost.
You can run this as a torture test too. (so the name fence of death)
Start from higher temperature then try lower the temperature every 5-10 degrees to see the results. You can adjust other settings for retraction, speed, etc. But I recommend playing with temperature first.
I found out the best temp. for my new PLA filament was in fact 175 degree to give the finest detail.
Print with a small brim for stability.

Notes:

Print with whatever setting you like.
But print this upright to see if it can stand! No cheating :P

title: Anet A8/AM8 2020 X-Axis 2020 for E3D V6/Titan Aero

description.text:
These are the parts that I made for the 2020 X-Axis mod. For V-Guide Z-Axis version see my design AM8 Z-Axis V-Guide. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2596722

Oct 29, 2017
Added Sensor mount for SN04, added Left and Right Single and Double Extrusion mount for anti-backlash nut.

Oct 16, 2017
Added three parts to mount 50mm axial fan and 40mm radial fan.

July 28, 2017
I have added a mount for the E3D Aero, I do not have a Aero so I do not know how well it works. Some of the parts for the E3D Titan Aero (fan mount, sensor mount and duct) are from GaryK47 design.

July 31,2017
Added Z-Axis limit switch mount for those not using auto level.
Added double 40mm fan duct.
Added 12mm, BL Touch sensor mount.
Sensor is located 31.6 or just 32mm to the right of the nozzle.

Aug 10,2017
Added X Axis Tension Mount-V3 for easier assembly.

Sept 15, 2017
Steps/mm for 30 tooth pulley

For 1/16th stepping use 53.33steps/mm
For 1/32th stepping use 106.67steps/mm

Example
M92 g-code can set the steps per mm in real time. Here is an example with your result for X axis.
M92 X53.33
Use M500 to save the setting.

Printer:

Anet AM8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

.2

50-75

comments.text: Hi, thanks very much for a wonderful design. Have you tested the z-bearings to see whether the double- or single bearing version is the best ? And why have you decided to go for one mounting hole instead of two as in the drawing ?
comments.author: mbunjes

comments.text: I found the single bearing design worked best for me but the double one is there if anyone wants to use it. I also found that one screw was enough to hold the mount in place, if you feel you need another hole you could just drill a second hole. I have have moved up to the V-Guide design which I feel is much better then the linear bearings. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2596722
comments.author: mbunjes

comments.text: I don't understand how to put the belt tensioner together, help?
comments.author: Fragged3d

comments.text: The X Tension Mount V3 makes it much easier to assemble. You need a long M3 screw about 30mm long. Put the M3 screw thru the hole in the X_AXIS_TENSIONER, lock the M3 screw in place with a M3 nut as it comes out of the hole, put the pulley in the X_AXIS_TENSIONER, put this assembly in the X_TENSION_MOUNT_V3, thread the belt in and around the pulley. Add the M3_NUT with a M3 nut inserted into this part to the M3 screw. Screw this all the down on the screw and place this assembly onto the 2020 extrusion.

title: Dungeon Dolls: Druid
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Ever like the variable designs of FlatMinis, but the customization of Dungeon Dolls? Ever wanted more options? Look no further! Inspired by the aesthetic of GrumpyRobot's FlatMinis, and DutchMogul's Dungeon Doll system, come Trixster_98's take on the classic Dungeon Doll.

This handy Druid includes two scimitars with differing handle placement (With each also mirrored), pants with pointed greaves, angular shirt, antlers coming out of their head, a trusty wolf, a plain base, or the elf base with hair. I printed mine at 150% which stands at 42 mm. Fully customizable and modular, look for more designs to come in the following weeks.

These designs are fully compatible with DutchMogul's original Dungeon Dolls, but not with FlatMinis
Made in Tinkercad, printed on my Monoprice MP Select Mini

Printing
The pieces should be printed at 150-200% depending on what you feel your printers accuracy to be. My printer can make all the details clearly visible at 100% but needs the print to be at 150% in order to fit together well.
The picture shows the 3 sizes of 200%, 150%, and 100%

Preparation
In order for the pieces to properly fit together, you will need to lightly sand them with a set of needle files. The heads just need very minute sanding in the eye holes. My first layer is always slightly off which always needs work in that one spot. The studs that attach to the shirt and pants need light sanding, but the holes should be fine, depending on your printers accuracy. The shirt stud typically needs a very small amount of sanding compared to the pant studs. The bottom that fits onto the base will most likely need sanding on both the hole and stud depending on accuracy.

Always test fit pieces together as you sand. I'm not responsible for ruined pieces due to too much sanding.

title: Coolice Hypercube Evolution Titan Aero & BLTouch Mount

description.text:
Hello.

This is my first item post and is a WIP.

I am currently building a Hypercube Evolution and want to mount a clone Titan Aero and extruder to the machine. Unfortunately as I don't yet have an assembled machine (awaiting replacement frame pieces as sent ones were cut too short), I cannot test this part yet, but it looks like it should work all ok. It mounts to the moving carriage as it should do.

What I did was take the existing back mounting plate details and erased the front hot end holder detail, this gave me the base to work from.
I then added my own design mounting fixtures to suit the Aero and also a BLTouch probe.
At the same time I also went down to one X axis optical end stop on the X min side, as the Duet board I am planning to use only uses one.

As my new printer is built any changes I make to this design I will post to keep this design up to date.

Also I will appreciate any feedback from users who try this design so that I can further improve it.

Revisions 2 added 14/8/17.
As yet Revision 2 of my Aero mount is untested, I have printed it and all seems fine, but I may need to lengthen or shorten the cooling duct if it's not in the right position to the hot end when I strip down the working Rev 1 assembly to fit these new components.

The cooling duct is designed to accept the small 5 volt laptop cooling fan, which looks and feels air flow wise like it should work all ok.
I have some others on order from Aliexpress; https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Centechia-Cooling-fan-for-F3-F3J-F3S-A8-Z99-X80-N80-N81-F8S-Z53-M51-F3H/32822995108.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.Ih9YaI which might require me to make some alterations to the design and provide an easily purchased fan at the same time
.
If I find out this fan type does not provide enough air flow, I will make a change for the duct to accept this type: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Anet-5015-24V-Ultra-quiet-Oil-Bearing-about-7500-RPM-Turbo-Small-Fan-3D-Printer-Accessories/32808457276.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.Ih9YaI

I've got one of each of the above fans on order so I can test both and decide which one works the best. Definetly the slim line one is neater so far.
Currenly I am using one I salvaged so will test that in the interim.

An M3 x 12mm and M3 x 16mm bolt and two M3 nuts are required to bolt the cooling duct to the bottom of the main Aero holder. I've made so that the duct can be remvoed to aid in printing head changes should it need to be removed to do so.

Also I have added another cable channel to the rear of where the pan cake stepper sits, this should allow the end stop wires and stepper wires to be guided up and out of the top of the tool holder.

9/10/2017 Coolice Aero Carriage without the BLTouch holding arm attached

9/11/2017 Coolice Aero Carriage without BLTouch holding arm, but with missing cooling fan duct mounting holes attached.

Also I am working on another varient of this design, this one having the part cooling duct bolted to the underside of the X Carriage part and thus seperate to the Coolice Aero Carriage so this makes hot end swaps eaiser.

Printer:

CTC Dual

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

35 ~ 50

Notes:

I'm printing all my parts in ABS currently for this printer build.

Due to the parts location I am using quite a high infill value, 45 in my case, which may be overkill but I'd rather have a strong part than a weaker one at this location.

comments.text: I'm in the same boat. Converting my hypercube evo to direct because bowden was giving me too much trouble. I think if you really want bowden to work well, you'd have to make additional mounting points for the extruder motor directly above the printer like several people have done. I mounted my motor to the side of my frame so the bowden tube bend changes significantly depending on the location of the carriage. I think that's where all my issues come from. I have another printer with a prusa style x axis which makes the tube much more consistent

comments.text: how lighter is the aero compared to common direct drive extruders?
comments.author: Manthos

comments.text:
Hey Buddy. To be honest I've not really weighed the two setups, so can't fully comment. But the main difference is in the stepper motor choice, as due to the gear ratio you can run one of the smaller pancake motors which is lighter than a normal Nema17 motor and still be able to drive filament through.
It's still not as light as an E3D with a bowden setup, but still a decent saving over the normal direct setups.
So far it's printing nicely in my first few prints on the new printer, just needs more dialling in now.

remixed_from.author: csorrows
remixed_from.title: Folgertech FT-5 Simple Solid Z Endstop

description.text:
After a few hours of work with a linear actuated dial indicator on a sweep arm, I realized the rear bearing mounting position is really not as rigid as needed for accurate return to home position.

This version -completely new files and design- mounts to the lead screw nut. This eliminates any movement of the print deck -that horrible Melamine thing- you would have on a stock FT-5 from messing with the repeatability of the Z Homing. The switch mount is designed to be large enough to be a stable platform, and protect the switch (you know you have stuffed your arm though there!!).
The insets for the 3mm nylock nuts and through holes for screws are generous in their tolerances, so you should have no issues printing this with a fresh FT-5 build (well..you shouldn't) and still be able to insert nuts, have holes line up. The switch mount is left and right handed so the connector is facing rearward, pay attention to what part your printing!! I used a 34mm screw to actuate the switch, longer would be better, maybe 40mm. If you are going to go E3D right away....let me know I can modify. You can just tap this hole, or possibly just patiently screw into it. the nut is optional.
The original files are completely restrained, so if you need some adjustment of the posts PM me, I can easily make changes for you. The post length required may vary from build to build depending on the actual length of your 20/20 extrusions, and how tight you get them together, and, if your melamine parts are the same as mine (IKR!!).

The dual Z-axis is an excellent mod that is simple and well documented, easily a top 4 "what should I mod first".

On the lower mount, you will want to use a 50% diagonal infill. Used Cura. HatchBox PLA

description.text:
This is a simple decorative Stargate SG-1 Power Crystal that lights up.
You insert a LED tea light in the base and that's that!

There are four different sizes of crystals to choose from so that you can mix and match.

Made to celebrate the 20th Anniversary of Stargate SG-1
Check out more Stargate fan stuff at https://www.facebook.com/SGCSWE/

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

The base should be printed with minimum infill and bed supports. Any opaque filament will do, I used PETG because why not... If you have any problems with bed adhesion, try adding a skirt/brim with zero offset, 1 layer and 5 outlines.

The crystals are designed to be printed in vase modem, single outline with no infill. I set 1 top and 3 bottom layers. I used transparent ABS for this, you can choose any transparent filament you have. Maybe even a colored one? :)

Assembly

The base is designed to fit a LED tea light with a diameter of 38mm and 'candle' height of 20mm. Example from amazon: https://www.amazon.com/Flameless-Candles-Realistic-Unscented-Tealights/dp/B00T28FWVS

The crystal has a thin membrane in its base that you need to remove after printing so that the 'flame' of the tea light can fit inside the crystal.
Slot the crystal in the socket and turn on the light.

Enjoy Stargate SG-1! :)
Entirely modeled in Fusion 360

description.text:
This is a motor/extruder mount for an ultimaker style rod setup, but with the motor mounted on the center, rather than at a distance with a bowden tube. After looking everywhere for this, I finally decided to design one myself. I wanted an ultimaker style gantry that allowed me to mount a direct drive extruder directly onto the gantry, rather than a bowden tube setup. I have been trying to print large prints with Ninjaflex, but bowden tubes kink up, even with an adapter on the extruder motor, they still manage to wrap around the extruder motor. Therefore, I decided to mount the extruder motor directly onto the cross bar style gantry, but still leave an opening for the motor, fan, and extruder setup. This eliminates the bowden tube problem, and still allows a reasonably large print volume.

I converted my Folgertech FT-5 completely to accommodate this design. The way I made it uses the existing parts in the kit, but increase the bed plate from 12x12x12 to 18x18x16. The only thing I needed were the bearing mounts and pulleys, also on my page, and 4 8mm smooth rods. I also used 2 5-8mm adapters for the z axis. I used the exising rods that came with the kit to make the ultimaker style rods for the gantry. I will post the complete build pics eventually.

This design is created to mount onto 4 15x24x8mm bore bushings. This will slide onto an 8mm rod. However, you may need to widen the holes slightly with a file or sandpaper, as it is a screwless compression fit. Two bearings are endstopped to fit flush with the surface, and the rods slide into that. The NEMA 17 motor also fits snugly into the channel left for it. I recommend expoxying the motor onto the mount to prevent it from sliding. Hot glue may work, but may soften with the heat of the motor.. At any rate, screws and a bracket somewhere would work too. This mount is designed to fit a 40mm fan that blows perpendicular to the fan on the motor.

The gantry motor is mounted to the direct drive style extruder that has a fan, then heatsink, then extruder, then motor, all held together with two long screws. The fan mounted on this assembly should be 40mm. Adjust the height as needed with your firmware.

This is definitely a project for an advanced builder. If you are not sure what any of this means, feel free to ask, and I will help you when I can. Enjoy!

Update:

I added a 16mm notch that will allow the electrical connector of the nema 17 motor to slide onto the gantry. This will allow you to put a 40mm fan on the back side to cool it or a bracket to hold the motor down.
This is strapmount i needed for my quad and i upload it here too if someone needs it.

This is a rendition of the controller device seen in Dr Who. I took a bit of liberty with the small details so they would print strong enough to withstand handling. This was for a friend of mine who does cosplay, so the interior space is hollow for adding LEDs/battery pack to light it up. I also designed in the cutout ledges and circular hollow to enable small hinges and a magnetic catch to be added to the case to make the prop a working clutch pocketbook. If you've been to a costumed convention, carrying around a big bag all day gets old. The parts have .2mm thick tabs to prevent curling up during printing, since this design relies on table flat pieces. The top was printed in clear ABS and the case and bottom in solid color, so LEDs could shine through the "lid" to match screen shots I had. Fine tune your printer flow, to prevent globbing and spider webs, so the thin decorative flourishes keep their detail.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 or .1 for best detail

Infill:

20 to 25 percent

Notes:

The magnetic catch was a small rare earth magnet and steel thumb tack, epoxied into the circular hollow in the sidewall of the case, and the lid right above it.

**UPDATE 25 JULY **** the small detail scrollwork was redone to make them stand out more, since some slicing programs would eliminate them as being to thin. The anti curl tabs on the case were repositioned and corner reinforcements put in to stop warping and layer splitting.

Painting

Mask off the irises and outer frame sections, prime and paint. Hand paint the shutters in the irises with liquid copper or brass. I floated a light cloud of metallic paint onto the clear sections to make them appear solid when the LEDs are off, but the light shines through when powered up.

This is a simple motor mount for a 2020 extrustion that allows you to mount the z stepper motors vertically. There is a notch on one face that allows the wiring connector to slide in.

Note: You may need to file a tiny bit of both sides of the notch to get the motor to sit flat on the bottom face. Otherwise, you will be scratching your head wondering why it seems bowed out. But better a tight fit than a sloppy one. Also, you will need to epoxy it to the surface, or find the type of screws that are in the motor bottom. They do not seem to be the same as the 2mm screws on the top, but I did leave holes for them should you find them (along with some washers) to hold it snugly in place.

If you make one of these, feel free to post a pic of your build. Enjoy!

description.text:
These OBJ models are designed for use in Sculptris and are designed to work with my Sculptris Dummies.. If you import them into Sculptris, their parts should remain separate and you can immediately begin sculpting and posing them any way you like. All of these parts are also available in Andrew Stockton's awesome Desktop Hero project as well (which is quite a bit easier than adjusting all the parts by hand).

If you make anything with these (including through Desktop Hero), let me know and post a link here in the comments section (and certainly post a remix when you have something printable). I'd love to see what you come up with!

You can find an expanding collection of compatible parts here.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

author: Mkhand_Industries

description.text:
This printer is awesome, it's strong, simple to build and has a large enough bed.
I've almost completed building it and I would like to show you how I remixed it.

Printer:

D-bot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

100%

Supports not needed

All supports are already in their place; remove them with pliers and cutter.

Remix 1

Deeply remixed the extruder(s) mount; it now features two extruders, a DB26 connector to use several tools (laser, mill ecc.) and a magnetic coupling to avoid that screwing/unscrewing; of course I remixed the X carriage too to reflect changes made.
I changed the blower duct to split air flow in two directions and changed its length according to my extruders length.
The DB26 connector works well for interchangeability of tools, 26 pins are enough for just everything and has acceptable dimensions; see schematic for wiring I'd suggest.

Remix 2

Added an Hall effect autolevel on rear of X carriage.
From long time I was trying to make a cheap, light and affordable level sensor for my printer but I didn't like none of these found around, 'til I discovered a very good idea on http://reprap.org/wiki/CrashProbe (read it carefully), so... at work!
The results were conforting, so here is my probe; it should works very well (not yet tested) with good repeatability (don't ask me about mills, microns and so on...).
It's intended to fit the X carriage using the belt clamps holes, but it's easily remixable in Tinkercad to fit your needs.
Based on a Hall sensor switch from https://it.aliexpress.com/item/Hall-Sensor-Magnetic-Module-Field-Detecting-Sensor-For-Arduino-Smart-Car-FreeShipping-Dropshipping/653186357.html

Remix 3

Redesigned the bed level mechanism with a new one more confortable to use, tnx to large knobs (not an idea of mine)

Remix 4

I own a Cyclops extruder and I decided to finally give it a try, so I designed a new support for it.
I re-designed the duct too, a little bit longer than the original and with different outlet angle.
I tried to maintain the (almost) same nozzle level from bed, to avoid re-align the bed.
Added a removable plate to support the extruder (fixing screws from rear 8-(( ) to maintain the same duct type.

BOM

Autolevel:

  • M3 screw 10mm (autolevel arm pin)
  • M3 screw 8mm (autolevel PCB adjusting)
  • 2 x M3 nut
  • a not very strong round magnet from 6x1mm to 6x3mm (Neodimium cube 5x5mm was too strong to work correctly), like these in fridge magnets
  • a metal pin 25x2.5mm (I used pin from a rivet)
  • spring from a ballpoint pen
  • cyan glue for magnets fixing
    Other stuff:
  • 2 x N52 Neodimium magnets 20x3mm
Autolevel instructions

The magnet must be strong enough to stick the arm nut when the probe is at the top, but must release it when the arm tilts.
Pay particular attention to what magnet side fire up the sensor, only one side make the trick!
Fix the nut into arm with cyan.
Drill the probe channel on the base with a 4.5mm tip.
Drill the arm hole with a 3.5mm tip.
The metal pin (see BOM) into the probe has to be lightly tight, so you can after find the right length; when done you can fix it with cyan.
Screw 4-5 turns of the spring (max length 4mm) around the probe and cut the remaining. This will help to avoid the magnet be sticking to arm when this rises.
Refine the probe (if necessary) to let it slide freely (really free!) into the base guides (bottom round and top square).
Much care must be used on magnet position.

To enable the probe is up to you to find a good point where to place a pin long enough to push the arm to initialize the probe.
As stated on Reprap Wiki, the bottom side of support (not the pin!) has to be about 5mm above the nozzle with pin extruding about 5mm.
Now it's up to you calibrating all the stuff, pin length and PCB height adjusting, to obtain good results as I did.

author: Yashua

description.text: I decided to add a top plate to the H8 MINI Light Frame to help keep the motors in place and protect the antenna. I have included the design spark mechanical files in case any one wants to make any modifications.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TBOkLRoWxTE&feature=youtu.be NOTE: The company that sold the lead screw drives for this design (Trinity Labs) has gone out of business. I have not yet found a replacement. That does not mean they are not out there somewhere. Just make sure you have them in hand before dedicating a tremendous amount of plastic to the construction of this machine. I do plan to revise the design to also use common off-the-shelf hardware, in which case it will be truly scalable on any axis. BE SURE TO DOWNLOAD THE LATEST BUILD PDF!
TankRap #1 has been commissioned and is working properly. Notes are in the construction PDF. Yoda tested at 70% reduced size, with .5mm hot end (white ABS, yellow PLA, see photo).
The TankRap is an easy-to-assemble 3D printer, built like a tank, with accuracy in mind. TankRap #1 survived international transit as checked luggage, and nothing broke. Testament to its ruggedness :) This is a complete file set to build a TankRap 3d printer with lead-screw X and Y drives.
This design is easily scalable in any axis, and the frame axes are designed to mount to plywood or acrylic to both enclose the work area and prevent frame torsion.
THIS IS A WORK IN PROGRESS. I have just finished constructing it and am now testing. So far the basic first design works correctly.
I do not recommend this project for someone's first 3d printer; it takes quite a bit of plastic to print everything, and the design may not be as easy to understand as some of the other opensource repraps available.
NOTE important: I originally designed this machine around the Bulldog XL extruder, but while testing, I have found the problem I have been having with extrusion lies not with the hot ends I have been using, but with the extruder itself. Perhaps I received a lemon, but until I get a replacement that works, I cannot recommend the Bulldog. I have redesigned the X carriage to hold a Greg/Wade Accessible Extruder and whatever hot end you can attach to it (I prefer my tried-and-true Buda hot ends from Airwolf 3D)

BE SURE TO DOWNLOAD THE LATEST BUILD PDF!
Print 8x cube vertex.
Print 2x Z motor mount.
Print 2x Z idler.
Print 1x everything else (choose X carriage based on hot end type).
Uses 2x Trinity Labs lead-screws for X and Y axes. http://trinitylabs.com/products/10-start-25mm-pitch-anti-backlash-nut-fast-lead-screws
Uses 1x Greg/Wade Hinged Accessible Extruder. I prefer the older model with the closed top guide. It seems to work much better for me. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11892
Uses 1x Reprapdiscount Rumba control board "big box" kit.
http://www.reprapdiscount.com/kits/62-rumba-big-box-with-smart-lcd-controller-endstops-mk2b-heatbed-1-wiring-set-capable-of-24v.html
Uses 5x NEMA stepper motors. 1xX, 1xY, 2xZ. Get high torque ones (40 newtons) if you can; they make a huge difference in reliability both in terms of accuracy and not-overheating-and-crashing your controller.
I recommend an Airwolf 3D hot end. I have used this on my other printer for a long time and it works great. http://airwolf3d.com/store/products/jr-jam-resistant-3d-printer-hot-end/
If using this hot end, print the buda type x-carriage and x-linkage.
Label all your parts with a sharpie as they come off the bed, so you can keep them organized. Due to some design slop, not all clamp pieces are universally compatible with other pieces.
I have scaled up all "internal" parts to 105%, so that bearings etc will fit better. Depending on your printer you may experience slight differences in print size. Always doublecheck with some sort of calibration tester before you print, to avoid waste, and modify the STLs as necessary.
Consider building a backup X and Y axis drive coupling because (a) they are designed thin to shear off in case of an endstop failure so the machine doesn't tear itself apart and (b) you may need to drill their holes out to get them to align better.
See PDF for detailed build instructions.
My copy of Configuration.h (for Marlin) is in here for the firmware, using a homemade Greg's Wade extruder, which may vary from yours. Most important are the acceleration settings-- default Marlin settings will cause a lot of skipped steps, mostly on Y, due to backlash.

title: Quanum Nova / Cheerson CX-20 Landing Gear for Gimbal and Action Camera

description.text: Since adding a Storm32 gimbal and SJCAM to my Quanum Nova quadcopter (aka Cheerson CX-20) I've been using rubber washers zip-tied to the bottom of the stock landing gear to make the quad tall enough to not hit the gimbal when it lands. In looking at the landing gear made by speedy777 on Thingiverse the model looked sound, but also still a little too short, so I added around 2cm to the height of the legs and increased the height of the skid slightly to match. The result fits my Quanum Nova great although the pins that attach the legs to the skids needed to be shaved down a little with a razor blade. Hope someone can make good use of this model, or if you need it printed please contact us at Access3DServices.com!

description.text:
These OBJ models are designed for use in Sculptris and are designed to work with my Sculptris Dummies.. If you import them into Sculptris, their parts should remain separate and you can immediately begin sculpting and posing them any way you like. All of these parts are also available in Andrew Stockton's awesome Desktop Hero project as well (which is quite a bit easier than adjusting all the parts by hand).

If you make anything with these (including through Desktop Hero), let me know and post a link here in the comments section (and certainly post a remix when you have something printable). I'd love to see what you come up with!

You can find an expanding collection of compatible parts here.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

comments.text: The fan isn't designed to blow on the build plate though. Warping is caused by the model cooling too quickly, which is why a lot of printers have heated beds and are enclosed to keep the temperatures up. The fan is only supposed to blow on the filament as it is laid down, which is what the built in one does. This will make it worse. Trust me, I've had this printer for a while and I've tried something similar while experimenting.

description.text:
First and foremost I would like to say this is my first project. I have no background in CAD, engineering, or design -- so if you find a way to improve on this design please be my guest.
This is a set of rear wheels for the Vaterra Glamis Uno/Fear but should also fit other 1/8 scale buggy or 2.2 x 50mm wheels.
This will fit the 50mm tires such as these:
1) http://www.redrockethobbies.com/Vaterra-Rear-Tire-Paddle-with-Foam-50mm-2-GLU-p/vtr44004.htm
2) http://www.horizonhobby.com/products/rear-tire-tetrapod-w-foam-med-50mm-2-glu-glf-VTR44003
Good luck and let me know if they work for you.

All you need is to print two of each, and 12 #4mm screws.
I've printed on my Up! Mini and tested the design on my buggy. These wheels work great and are designed with extra-strength in mind. I printed with "raft", .35 for the test (don't remember the infill).
For added strength you can dip them in acetone or print solid.
Let me know if you print one or how it goes for you.

title: Dungeon Dolls: Skeleton
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Ever like the variable designs of FlatMinis, but the customization of Dungeon Dolls? Ever wanted more options? Look no further! Inspired by the aesthetic of GrumpyRobot's FlatMinis, and DutchMogul's Dungeon Doll system, come Trixster_98's take on the classic Dungeon Doll.

This handy Skeleton includes a bone weapon, skeletal body, skeletal head, and a skeletal base. Try mixing with other characters for more types of skeletons. I printed mine at 150% which stands at 42 mm. Fully customizable and modular, look for more designs to come in the following weeks.

These designs are fully compatible with DutchMogul's original Dungeon Dolls, but not with FlatMinis
Made in Tinkercad, printed on my Monoprice MP Select Mini

Printing
The pieces should be printed at 150-200% depending on what you feel your printers accuracy to be. My printer can make all the details clearly visible at 100% but needs the print to be at 150% in order to fit together well.
The picture shows the 3 sizes of 200%, 150%, and 100%

Preparation
In order for the pieces to properly fit together, you will need to lightly sand them with a set of needle files. The heads just need very minute sanding in the eye holes. My first layer is always slightly off which always needs work in that one spot. The studs that attach to the shirt and pants need light sanding, but the holes should be fine, depending on your printers accuracy. The shirt stud typically needs a very small amount of sanding compared to the pant studs. The bottom that fits onto the base will most likely need sanding on both the hole and stud depending on accuracy.
The ribs on the skeleton have a tendency to break whilst removing supports. Be careful.
Supports are not strictly necessary. I tried without at 150 % and it worked

Always test fit pieces together as you sand. I'm not responsible for ruined pieces due to too much sanding.

description.text:
After building a Dactyl keyboard I found myself needing wrist rests to type on it comfortably. Adereth provides a model but I wasn't quite satisfied with the dimensions, and the SCAD for it is illegible stuff generated from Clojure, so I rolled my own straight in SCAD.

They're dimensioned with the Kinesis wrist pads in mind, as I had some lying around, which is the black pads you can see on them in the pictures. I made the height to fit what I find comfortable, might be you want something different. Under the legs there are indents for putting little rubber feet as you can see in the pictures, to make them grip the table surface better and not slide around. Everything is parameterized and can be customized.

It's here if you want it.
I only used this a short time then designed this...
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24716

3D printed.
Was indented to be mounted by using a longer screw on the extruder mount but I've found it works OK held on by rubber band.
V1 has a clearance problem if you use my z-poker.
V2 to just clears the V1 poker (see image) but would need some work to clear the glue-on V2-poker.
You can tap the fan screw hole to M3 or drill out and use a nut.
Note the faces of V2 almost touch and it prints with the hole there - it is still quite strong - it is not a bug it is a feature.

title: Roller Shade LIft Cord System DIY

description.text:
More photos and instructions to come, once I finish first Roller Shade install this week.

Design objective was to create a Universal Roller Blind Pulley System, simple parts that could be used to make DIY Roller Blinds for widths of up to 10 feet !! ..or as narrow as wanted. The same pulley assembly can be used for 2-3 times across the blind width, and the same pulley assembly is used for routing the draw cords to either the left or right side of the blind. The shade is easily lifted out of hangers (useful in outdoor applications, to stow for winter).

The Universal Roller Blind Pulley assembly uses a 5 x 23mm piece of shaft or tubing, for the pulley axle. Optionally 2 M3 or self tapping screws can be used to hold the assembly together prior to mounting on top shade rod. Note that the lift cord can pass straight through the pulley assembly, or wrap around the pulley and exit at 90 or 180 degrees .. many options! (tip: insert end of lift cord into pulley assembly, poke through holes to force cord to exit through desired hole).

The upper shade rod should be flat sided wood .. preferably a 2 x 2 or 2 x 4 ripped down the middle (table saw). Note that there 2 types of Upper Rod end mounts, one for a 2 x2 piece of lumber, and another for the slightly wider ripped 2 x 4. Wind the shade material around this wood piece, with double sided tape, and apply staples on non-visable sides (3 sides usually) .. mount Universal Pulleys on front visible side, using wood screws.

The lower Rolling rod, is a low cost piece of schedule 40 1-1/4" PVC pipe ..(tip: paint a couple inches of each end, which may be visible with shade material rolled on. Insert the 3D printed end caps in each end some force required, also FILL the PVC pipe with sand, or alternative material, for added weight, prior to inserting 2nd end cap .. if your caps fit snug to loose, add glue. NOTE: the filler weight in the PVC pipe really helps the shade roll tightly and straight, and helps resist the wind outdoors. Attach lower rolling rod to shade using double sided tape on the bottom 4-6" of shade material that will always remain rolled onto this lower rod. Some care must be taken to squarely position the upper and lower rod when double sided taping them in place.

Note that the design of the lift cord anchors, allows looping the cord around an internal boss, to tie off the cord on (use a square knot). This greatly increases the strength of the lift cord attachment, over simply knotting up the cord to resist pulling through the anchor hole. This is a much cleaner looking solution, compared to the eyelet screws used by most DIY'ers.

Once the roller shade is set at desired position, fix the position by tying off the lift cords to an appropriate cleat (many are on Thingiverse .. my preference was this one https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2323392 .. I liked the shape, and printing orientation which should be strong for this application use). If your shade is fairly long, I recommend using 2 cleats per shade, spaced vertically apart. The very long cord can be wound between the 2 cleats then wrapped off on one.

For finishing your lift cord ends, I also suggest using this nice traditionally styleed cord end pull https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:334895 ... FYI - there are many other styles on Thingiverse to choose from.

Example Roller Blind Build: a 60" wide x 7' tall Canvas blind for an outdoor Gazebo. A total of 3 Universal Roller Blind pulley assemblies are used. Canvas material ~ $14, tape/glue ~ $2, 5' PVC 1 1/4 sch40 pipe ~$4, Lift Cord 1.8mm dia ~$4... complete blind assembly cost ~ $24 (compare to $60-100 for a commercial unit in limited fabric type & color options).

I bought this packet (http://www.rhombus.be/contents/nl/p1809_Basic_Turbine_Building_Parts.html) to experiment with wind power. It contains out a generator, mounting for the windmill wings and sticks to hold the wings. You can buy a base with it, i prefer to engineer it mystelf.

you need
1x motormount
3x bottom
3x verhoging for the height

If you want to go higher you can use koppelstuk to attach 2 x verhoging together.

The couplings are not a tight fit so i use a polymer glue to attach the parts together.
The reason that larger parts are in seperate pieces is because i use the hobby printer Vertex K8600 that prints in a volume of 8x8x8cm

I only need to attach the bottom pieces to a heavy surface and shorten the wooden sticks a little bit and then constructing wings for it to test out the effeciency. I used 2 middle pieces together it all depends on how large your wing design is.

These OBJ models are designed for use in Sculptris and are designed to work with my Sculptris Dummies.. If you import them into Sculptris, their parts should remain separate and you can immediately begin sculpting and posing them any way you like. All of these parts are also available in Andrew Stockton's awesome Desktop Hero project as well (which is quite a bit easier than adjusting all the parts by hand).

If you make anything with these (including through Desktop Hero), let me know and post a link here in the comments section (and certainly post a remix when you have something printable). I'd love to see what you come up with!

You can find an expanding collection of compatible parts here.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

Coming from a Printrbot Simple Metal, the CR-10 had a very clunky hot end arrangement. You really can't see anything being printed. I made a new one to help direct both the part fan and the hot end cooling fan more efficiently.
NOTE: the files are not pre-translated to their best printing orientation. Print with supports

You'll need 4 M3 15mm bolts to mount the hot end fan to shroud.
There are a total of 8 bolts on the default machine that must be removed: 2 holding the shroud, four inside the shroud for the hot end, two for the hot end, and four on the outside of the shroud for the part cooling fan.
Use the hot end mounting bolts through first the holes in the Fan_Shroud and then through the hot end to secure the Shroud in place. You'll need to take off the two spring washers to get them to the right length.
Put the M3 bolts through the fan_mount, the 40mm hot end fan, and then thread into the hot end shroud. Ensure the square of the fan_mount is on the right side of the hot end.
Finally, attach the part cooling fan using the original bolts in the same fashion as the original mount, swapping out the old fan nozzle with the new one.

description.text:
Derivative project from my bridge. Created to fill the gap of small bridges which are made faster using a small balsa sustain and adding only the lateral parts. It's been designed looking at real small railway bridges, which are constructed with an open-upper-part frame, with only a lateral steel structure.
There is a starter part, which can be rotated pre-print to create all the orientations needed and a middle section, usable to elongate the structure to suit necessity.
The whole file is given to get a view of how it should seem when assemblied, it's not intended for printing. (if you got a printer supporting that printing area, be my guests, though).

title: Sculptris OBJ Bits: Fantasy Pants and Skirts
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These OBJ models are designed for use in Sculptris and are designed to work with my Sculptris Dummies.. If you import them into Sculptris, their parts should remain separate and you can immediately begin sculpting and posing them any way you like. All of these parts are also available in Andrew Stockton's awesome Desktop Hero project as well (which is quite a bit easier than adjusting all the parts by hand).

If you make anything with these (including through Desktop Hero), let me know and post a link here in the comments section (and certainly post a remix when you have something printable). I'd love to see what you come up with!

You can find an expanding collection of compatible parts here.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

author: jstarr2643

description.text:
A work in progress! I'd suggest printing V3, however I have only printed V2 and it works pretty well.

Currently designing and printing a simple left-handed grip for my Mamiya M645J. This should be compatible with all the cameras in the M645 line-up, but I'm not certain. Hopefully this makes the camera slightly more ergonomic to use.

The attachment point is through the tripod screw, and I'm using a screw from an old film camera leather case. Reason being is that it's got a large surface to grip the plastic once tightened down. You'll probably have to modify the fastener location depending on your available hardware. You may be able to get away with a short bolt that is the correct size of the camera, and a large washer to fit inside the counter-bore (it's got a diameter of 0.98 in which is ~25mm)

Let me know if you have any questions! I'll be updating it as I tweak it/make it fit properly.

Update #1: V2 should be properly sized now. Increased distance between camera body and grip, as well as increased finger divot size and decreased bottom pin diameter. The addition of a stiffening rib should also help the strength of the part.

Update #2: V3 has been released, which integrates a ~10 degree rotation to the grip. This should provide a more comfortable handhold, as it also emulates the production grip design. The stiffening rib has also been increased in size to try and minimize the deflection of the grip when in use.

title: Fiberon 45 degree Support For Longer Bottom Rail Brackets

description.text:
It appears there are 2 sizes of Fiberon Attachments. A shorter (measured from short end bottom to top) and a more elongated design. This is a remix of the shorter to accommodate the height of the longer piece.
Update: The reason there are height differences is to accommodate different steepness of stair rails. The longer size here can accommodate a much steeper rail. Just found that out. The shorter one is for straight runs and limited angles on the railing.

description.text:
This is a remix of vik's tea bowl in which I:

  • created a more "closed" shape by cutting off the flared upper body 胴 (dō)
  • enable gripping of the tea bowl—e.g., for wiping it—by creating a 高台内 (kōdai-uchi), formed by hollowing out a shallow cylinder from the kōdai

The version seen in the photograph is tea-bowl-rev2.stl but vertically stretched in the slicing software. This vertical stretch is incorporated into tea-bowl-rev3.stl, as is an attempt at a rounded lip.

This bowl still suffers some flaws from a functional point of view: it lacks a concave 茶溜まり (chadamari), but most importantly the lip 口造り (kuchitsukuri) is not round enough for a comfortable drinking experience. I'm working on addressing these shortcomings with future tea bowl designs.

Made in Fusion 360.

Model crayfish with 21 points of articulation.  
I'm entering it in the #OnSuchAFullSea competition, though technically it's not a fish... and it's a freshwater animal not marine! Shhh, hopefully no one will notice!  
The claws and tail segments are designed to use pieces of 1.75mm filament offcuts as hinges. All 10 legs are attached to the body on ball joints. No glue required, though it may help if the main parts feel too loose.  
Modelled and sculpted in Blender. Plated and prepared for export in 3ds Max.

Crayfish_Assembly_Instructions.pdf
Full assembly instructions with pictures. Crayfish_STL.zip [recommended]
This contains all parts plated into small groups of related parts. You may wish to print several groups at once depending on your build-volume. Crayfish_Individual_STL.zip
This contains each part in a separate STL file. Don't forget to print 2x copies of each of the 4 leg files (a total of 8 walking legs).

This model is designed to print without support.  
Some of the parts require very good platform adhesion so they don't fall over. PLA works very well on blue painter's tape. Alternatively set your slicer / print software to generate a "brim".  
The hinge pin holes are sized at 2mm for making pins from 1.75mm filament offcuts. If you only use 3mm feedstock (eg. Ultimaker) you could resize the model to 150%. At this scale the biggest piece will be just under 130mm tall.

Crayfish_Assembly_Instructions.pdf
Full assembly instructions with pictures. Crayfish_STL.zip [recommended]
This contains all parts plated into small groups of related parts. You may wish to print several groups at once depending on your build-volume. Crayfish_Individual_STL.zip
This contains each part in a separate STL file. Don't forget to print 2x copies of each of the 4 leg files (a total of 8 walking legs).

author: PabloNada

title: Base Clip needed for Print-in-place Iris Box when printing it large

description.text:
Technically this is not a remix of the brilliant Print-in-place Iris Box by LoboCNC. Just a required minor addition for it when printing much larger than 100% size.

I originally printed LoboCNC's Iris box at the standard 100% size and found it to be too small to really use as a useful storage container and i also found he iris leaves and the outer sphere of the print were just too thin at the standard size, so i scaled it up. The Y Axis of my printer has a max size of 145mm so that was as large as i was able to print. I scaled the file to 220% which gave me a size of approx 140mm in the X and Y direction. I also had to print at 0.3mm layer height for it to print properly at this size because scaling it up that much made the internal gaps larger and the start of the rotating outer section would fail at any smaller layer height (due to too many layers of gap below it).

The other issue with printing larger is that the outer rotating sphere is very loose (once again due to all tolerance gaps being made larger with the scale). Because of this and the weight of the iris leaves the box would not say closed and would simply fall open when letting go of the outer sphere.

These clips stop this from happening by taking out the looseness of the outer sphere and putting some friction between the bottom base ring and the rotating outer shell, enough that the sphere wont twist accidentally, even when being jostled of knocked, but still opens and closes very easily when you twist it by hand.

Also please note that this clip is sized to work with the Iris Box when printed at 220% scale, if you print your iris box at a larger scale again, then you will need to scale these to match!

You can either print 3 clips and have them spaced around the base ring every 5 bumps, or you can print 5 clips and have them spaced every 3 bumps, it doesn't seem to make any difference to the operation, just personal preference i suppose.

The clips just need a tiny smear of super glue on the inside then slide over the base ring and hold in place for 10-20 seconds. I would also recommend NOT twisting the box for an hour afterwards to make sure the clips are well and truly glued firmly into place before using it.

Here are a couple of video's showing the iris box at 220% before and after fitting the clips:

Before - https://www.dropbox.com/s/fzod8jhfyyy202y/20170715_195505.mp4?dl=0

After - https://www.dropbox.com/s/zy4ymwdvfzu028u/20170716_013324.mp4?dl=0

I would also add that, the iris box really does benefit from being printed larger, it feels so much more sturdy and substantial.

ENJOY! :-)

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
My other schmidt coupling design:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:233667
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ Schmidt couplings have the ability to connect two shafts that are misaligned or that undergo changes in radial displacement during operation. Because there is an equal balance of pushing and pulling forces amongst the two sets of links, the two forces overlap in a sinusoidal pattern which makes possible the transfer of constant torque between the input and output shaft regardless of their radial displacement. All pivots are 1/8th" (~3 mm) plastic rod stock (or 3mm filament) that are captured by flattening both ends with a heated object after assembly. If you don't have either of those, I've included .stl files for 1/8th/3mm pivots, but I have not printed them myself. They will likely need to be printed laying on the side, and should be sanded to uniformity. Or scaled up 5-10% and sanded, if the previous ones come to be too loose in the mechanism. *The front upright with adjustment slider/tab should be left separate until complete assembly of everything else. *Once the output shaft is in place, the front upright with adjustment tab added should be pushed onto the shaft, and the bottom of the upright then glued to the base plate. Before the glue has fully set, crank the mechanism to check for alignment issues (side to side) and reposition the upright as needed for all 3 plates to visually overlap in phase from a frontal view, and to remain perpendicular to the base from a side view, when the shaft is slid into the lowest and upward positions. Since the schmidt coupling allows for freedom of movement on a 2D plane, the former alignment is just for aesthetics rather than function. Parts Reference:
CrankShaft (teal/blue) 2X
EndPlate (red) 2X
MidPlate (green) 1X
Links (yellow) 6X
Spacers (pink) 12X
Pivot(short) 6X
Pivot(long)3X http://youtu.be/E_YXZDF7vYs

I had warping issues with the larger (rear) upright, so I printed it standing up. I printed the front upright lying down and it warped a little bit but not enough to mess up the print and I was able to straighten it easily with a heat gun.  Next time I would probably print that one standing up, too.

description.text:
I made a keychain based on Aggressive Retsuko, an one-minute episode anime series wherein a red panda gets frustrated with cooperate life and vents though Death Metal. (http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2016/03/21/sanrios-aggressive-retsuko-explores-the-joys-of-work-and-death-metal) (The kanji on her forehead says 'Rage')

The .STL model is larger than necessary. I shrank my keychain down to 60mm in width. You should also be able to squash down the height too if you are looking for a thinner keychain or charm. Basically, alter the size for what you want.

I also included a model without the keyring in case anyone wants that.

I did not print my model with a raft, but I probably should have (there is a little curling), and the small gaps you might see on my photo at the ears and hands in due to me not fine-tuning my extrusion setting.
Use supports to the printbed for the hands.

I totally welcome any feedback. This is my first printed model I've designed from scratch.

title: XT60 Snap
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I designed this XT60 snap primarily for use on mini quads so that during a crash, the plug doesn't become disconnected thus disabling telemetry and the buzzer. I use high-quality lipo straps so the battery never ejects but got tired of spending countless hours searching for my quad when the lipo gets disconnected in a crash.

This snap has gone through several iterations and is designed for a non-intrusive ease of use and installation to your existing setup. Simply zip tie the snap in between the two frame side power leads. Be sure to add a strain relief to the frame side power leads to prevent any stress on the attached components.

Yet another Minecraft creeper model, because there isn't enough of them on here :)

I didn't like the overhang artifacts on the faces of the one-piece models on here, so I threw this one together, which prints as two separate pieces for better finished quality. Print the head (creeper_head.stl) face-up, and print the body (creeper_body.stl) upright. Then glue the two pieces together.

The design is scaled so that 1 "minecraft pixel" (is that the right word?) is 1mm, so you'll probably want to scale it up for printing. As shown on my print bed here, they were scaled 300x.

OpenSCAD design files are attached if you want to mess with the design. Enjoy!

This is a toy spinning top modeled to resemble a hand grenade. in addition to the printed files a 0.5 inch diameter wooden dowel, 3 feet of string and a key-ring are needed to finish the top. Cut the dowel to 4 7/16 inches long and drill a 1/8 hole in the center of the dowel 7/16 inched down from the top. Insert the dowel into the bottom piece of the top with the hole in the dowel at the opposite end as the top bottom. Now tie the key-ring into the end of your string. Insert the bottom of the top into the top section. Stick the end of the string into the hole in the dowel and wind string around the dowel. Now pull on the key-ring while holding the top portion of the top and watch it spin.

description.text:
L-bracket I made for Canon 5D Mark II-IV and 6D, but it should fit other DSLRs as well. Printed this in Carbonfiber PETG 5 layers all around and 50% triangle infill. After printing snap off the support and the lower bars on the arca style dove tail and re-cut the 1/4-20 treads. Ad a 1/4-20 camera screw. You could ad a rubber piece in front of the lower left corner of the camera. Included is a piece I printed in Ninjaflex and glued into that corner for a secure fit of the camera. The bracket seems fairly indestructible and is completely inflexible.

Update: Version 2 is slimmer and fits the 5DM2 more tightly. Realized the material is strong enough for this smaller version.

description.text:
Orquilli­n is an spray air freshener dispenser in the shape of a Killer Whale also known as Orca or Blackfish.  
Orquilli­n not only looks nice, it also makes your place smells nice and fresh!  
Originally it was thought out to be a wall-mounted bathroom-only accessory, but through several iterations evolved into its current shape, so set it free!... to wander anywhere inside you house, freshening the air wherever it goes...

Print each of the four parts separately:
Upper_body
Lower_body
Clamp
Spots For better looks print the lower body and the spots with white filament and the upper body with black filament. Print the clamp in either color. Either ABS or PLA should work although I have only printed it using ABS. Insert the spots on the upper_body.
Insert the clamp on the lower_body.
snap together the upper and lower body by the joint.
Insert aromatic cartridge.
Squeeze!, and set it free!

description.text: I was starting to get a pile of SD cards going and was having some difficulty finding older projects to re-print. Several have posted some holders for the actual SD cards themselves, but I happen to have a box of #1 coin envelopes (pictured) and I wanted to use those because, as you can see, I can actually write on the envelope to see what's on the card inside. Also, and this is a personal thing, I buy 64MB and 128MB cards because for one thing they're fairly inexpensive, and because they only hold so much G code, I don't have this epic list of projects that I have to try and cram on the front of the envelope. I also printed an extra box to hold blank envelopes and empty SD cards. (Oh, and it's no fun scrolling through a long list of files on a small LCD screen...)

Make you own amazingly beautiful jellyfish, with this openSCAD file, or use the customizer right in your browser.
These print without any goofing in the gcode. make, download, slice and print.
I am exploring deliberately making drooloops, (I made that word up, droop+loop) and trying to harness the neat shapes you can get. This is my second attempt at something neat. Please let me know how your prints turn out and post pics. EDIT - I fixed the trouble, I was using the "resize" command in openSCAD which thingiverse does not support, I have recoded my file to use the "scale" command. phew! enjoy (FIXED)I have this as "in progress" and may have to post more files since the customizer seems to be having trouble with the bell. Download the file and run it local it works great. Also trying to get this in before the OnSuchAFullSea contest closes. :-)

These are really fun to design and print. Each print job is fun since there's a slight element of randomness. The randomness is because we are deliberately "printing in the air" to create the "drooloops" (droop+loop) that make these jellies look so amazing. These slicer settings worked well so far with the models I have uploaded, or any customizer you make if you don't change settings on the advance tab of the customizer version.
ALL UNITS millimeters (mm)
layer_height = 0.2
wall_thickness = 0.8
solid_layer_thickness = 0.8
fill_density = 17
support = None
platform_adhesion = None
solid_top = True
solid_bottom = True Feel free to experiment and let everyone know if you find improvements or just interesting results. One person's "interesting results" may be another person's "that exactly what I was looking for!".

description.text: Paradoxical gears is a concept I reversed engineered around Oskar Van Deventer and his renditions on Paradoxical gears. From his YouTube video's (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qGAnmRb66s0) and other references, I designed a model of my own that works pretty much identically. The weird thing about how these work is that three identical gears can turn in the same and opposite directions depending on how they turn. Sure they're totally inefficient, but really fascinating and counter intuitive if you ask me.

You'll need three Lego axles longer than three studs long. Insert into the base, and orient the gears as shown in the picture. Two facing the same way, one flipped upside down. You'll need to either insert all the gears at once, or put the gears together on a desk and put the axles in from the top. The latter is probably faster, but not nearly as fun as fumbling around with gears for a good 5 minutes!

title: Ultimaker 3 / Ultimaker 2 Offset Mount for Large Spools

description.text:
We like running the large colorFabb Economy PLA spools on the printers at our shop, but also like the convenience of mounting the spool on the back of our Ultimaker 3D Printers. So, we came up with this nifty little adapter plate to move the spool off to the side.

Works on Ultimaker 2 and 3 printers with the existing spool holder. This is an offset spool mount to make it easier to use large spools Note that if you're using the Ultimaker 3, it will block access to one extruder, but still handy overall.

Components for AEG's Automobiles by David Short.

During our plays of the game the plastic trays for the cubes always seemed to get in the way and tip over or be hard to use while playing.

Included is a newer cube tray that will fit 5 different colors of cubes (and still fits in the box), a little display hangar to set the cards on, and a lid you can use to cap the top of the cube tray.

Print the Card Display with "Support Everywhere" setting on cura or whatever slicer you use, then once printed rip out the supports. The left side and top of the card display should be "loose", if you need to use a paperclip or something to "crimp" the cards in place in case they slide around too much.

print_settings.Notes:: This model was designed to print without support and the Infill level can be whatever you want.

description.text:
Our house had a bunch of 30 degree wire shelves but the original support design was weak and several have broken over time.

This is my attempt at creating something stronger. It's basically an I-Beam that has been rounded to print without supports. The I-Beam also supports both faces to prevent them from fracturing along the center line (the most common failure point).

description.text:
I remixed lilfonzy's Low-Voltage Bracket to make the arms stronger. I printed out his version and the arms were far too flimsy and broke quite easily. In this version the arms are an order of magnitude stronger and don't interfere with the overall design or shape.

UPDATE: I added the missing arms .stl (oops) and also made the model printable without supports! Yay! The screw hole edges are now tapered at a 45° angle so they're basically the perfect countersunk screw holes now.
